Definition: In this task, you will receive a public comment from online platforms. You are expected to divide the comment into two classes: insult and non-insult. Insulting is any language or action that is disrespectful or contemptuous.

Positive Examples.input: Comment: No wonder Hillary got beat by a circus clown.
Positive Examples.explanation: This comment is insult because it is scornful and disrespectful.

Comment: In regards to the question of non-unanimous jury verdicts, Perlow claims that, "a criminal defendant can benefit from having 10 of 12 people voting to acquit".  If unanimous verdicts were required, a defendant would benefit from a hung jury with 10 of 12 voting to acquit, because if the prosecutor polled the jury and found that 10 people voted to acquit, he would be unlikely to re-file charges and go to trial again.
If a jury votes 10 of 12 to convict a person, it means that the prosecutor has failed to prove his case "beyond a reasonable doubt", because the two people voting to acquit had enough reasonable doubt to acquit. Since a person is presumed innocent until proven guilty (beyond a reasonable doubt), a person in this case should still be considered to be innocent. In that case the prosecutor has the option of re-filing the charges and trying the case again.

Comment: Eveyone on here is pro Uber, probably because they think fares will be dirt cheap. There are plenty of downsides to ride sharing services. As has been mentioned here they exploit drivers, often coercing them to take loans from Uber affiliated finance companies at inflated interest to buy vehicles based on unrealistic promises of income. Ride sharing services pay no workmans comp, health insurance or other employment benefits to their "non-employee" workers.
Ever wonder why Uber can charge $4 for a ride across town vs $20 for a cab? Most readers probably assume the real cost is $4 and the cab company is a rip off. The truth is that the fares charged by Uber only cover 42% of the cost of the ride. The rest is funded by their investors. This means fares will eventually go up substantially  once the competetion has been crushed by artifically low subsidized rates, unless Silicon Valley investors somehow decide to subsidize cheap rides in Anchorage forever.

Comment: Mr. Osman, again I reiterate that there is no exclusionary policy being discussed here. What is being contemplated is an indigenous government operating under the supremacy of the United States. This indigenous government would for the most part only have jurisdiction over its members, and only over specific parcels of land. There is a clear difference between this construct and the 90's independence movement, in which some extremists argued that all non-Hawaiians should be forced to leave an independent Hawaiian government. 

Through the reorganized Native Hawaiian government we would not be a new state or replace the state. We would not have the authority to change your rights under state and federal law,and definitely not to kick people out of the state! We would however have the opportunity to determine our own affairs and deal directly with the U.S. 

I suspect that for most day to day activity there would be little change in the lives of non-members.

Comment: GMOs increase herbicide use. Most GM crops are engineered to be "herbicide tolerant"―surviving deadly weed killers. Monsanto, for example, sells Roundup Ready crops, designed to survive applications of their Roundup herbicide. Between 1996 and 2008, US farmers sprayed an extra 383 million pounds of herbicide on GMOs. Overuse of Roundup results in "superweeds," resistant to the herbicide. This is causing farmers to use even more toxic herbicides every year. Not only does this create environmental harm, GM foods contain higher residues of toxic herbicides. Roundup, for example, is linked with sterility, hormone disruption, birth defects, and cancer.

Comment: I am not disputing the fact that especially Vancouver through the 1997 Hong Kong pass over and beyond has been an attractive place for Asian families.  I am simply saying that in terms of affordability we are at the 1989 level in Toronto today.  house prices have increased a great deal, but interest rates make about the same level of affordability, and in fact a little cheaper.

And so yes, it is cyclic, prone to booms and busts, but the secular trend is up based on more demand. As an aside, where I live in Toronto (my sister lives in Vancouver) the majority of the buyers are speculators.  either sitting on houses, knocking them down and building bigger ones or gutting them for resale. Or put another way, the marginal buyer in 416 is not the same as the marginal buyer in 604.

Comment: What I'm curious about is the fees in a mutual fund whose constituent investments are also mutual funds.  Each fund has a cost made up of its trading expenses and many other things. The return of each fund is net of its costs. So when the fund that is made up of other funds says that its MER is say 2.3% I'm guessing that doesn't include all of the expenses for the funds under it. Rather its MER is just its own cost which is subtracted from the net returns of its constituent elements to determine the subscriber's return on his investment product that invests in other investment products. I'd be interested to have somebody confirm or contest my interpretation stating your qualification or specific source of knowledge. Thank you.

Comment: I've been watching the committee meetings online (the Senate provides a live feed)… and it seemed like pretty standard stuff. When regulatory changes are proposed, it's customary to seek out "stakeholders" to act as witnesses. In this case, the committee received testimony both from groups representing the tobacco and vaping industries, and from anti-tobacco groups, including the Non-Smokers' Rights Association quoted in this article.

I can't imagine senators or MPs being "unaware" of the relationship between CCSA and the tobacco industry, as Ms. Tilson herself raised the issue several times during her testimony yesterday, and today it was the subject of a direct question aimed at one of the tobacco execs.

In any case, a focus on funding relationships distracts from the actual legislation the government is proposing. Bill S-5 would introduce major legal changes that need to be discussed on their merits (or lack thereof) alone.

Comment: The author needs to look a bit harder.  Instead of looking at career politicians, he should look at the broader population.

Jill Stein's support is up around 5% in the national polls (5 x more than the Greens normally earn).  As Jill's policies are more or less identical to Bernie's, I think it's a safe bet that almost all of her supporters would have voted Democrat, if the Democrats had chosen Sanders.  I think we can safely put that 5% down as #NeverClinton Progressives.  

Gary Johnson is doing even better (around 10% - 10 x more than the Libertarians normally earn) and while he's drawing support from Republicans who believe he represents their values a lot better than Trump does, it's also clear from the four-candidate polls that he is pulling his fair share of voters (#NeverClinton Democrats?) from Clinton as well.

#NeverClinton Democrats exist.  Its just a question of whether there are enough of them - and #NeverTrump Republicans - to make a difference.

Comment: Except that high income earners in Canada *DO* pay taxes, a LOT of taxes.

In fact the top 10% of earners in this country pay more than half of all income taxes that are paid, an amount vastly in excess of their proportion of income.  They not only are paying "their fair share", they are also paying the "fair share" for everyone else.  The way our tax system is setup losing only a very small proportion of high income earners in Canada would result in the complete collapse of our social programs because they are covering the lions share of the cost.

On a per capita basis an individual needs to earn somewhere $90,000/year just to break even on the taxes they pay vs. the per capita cost of government services.

Comment: I'm sitting here procrastinating, before going out to the garden. I do pray there, and the general work of gardening, the thing itself, is offered as a sort of prayer, but it is not dedicated to any particular saint. It's intended for the people living in the immediate vicinity. At the moment, there are six people/families that are growing vegetables, my wife's flower border, open space for children to run around, a few benches, and a low tree-house/platform, also for the young. And a drinking fountain, near the center.  I don't  consider it mine to name or dedicate. For me, I think it mostly serves as  a God-in-You garden. A priest-friend told me I ought to have a figure of Mary out their, and that was nice to think about. I thought that if there was it would best be in the form of a mosaic, composed of some of the too-abundant glass, pottery, tile and etc. that comes out of the ground here. I could do such a thing, but in a way it seems redundant, and there are other tasks to attend.

Comment: We didn't have a say in the voting process, your statement is quite false and misleading.  

There was an open call for nominations and an independent advisory council was selected to choose out of those submitted.  Canadians were able to submit a formal opinion survey on the long list, twelve nominations who were chosen by the council, to gauge their decisions.  The advisory council also submitted a short list of five nominees and did focus group testing of those five to see what the reaction would be.  This short list of five choices was then submitted  to the Governor of the Bank of Canada and the Minister of Finance.  The Minster made the final choice.  

Nowhere did we vote for anyone on the bill.  We were given the ability to submit an opinion survey on twelve nominees already chosen, not of the entire list.  Granted, submissions were originally taken publicly, but we did not get to vote on the list.

http://www.bankofcanada.ca/banknotes/banknoteable/selection-process/

Comment: Any kind of coercion in voting, or undue influence during the voting process, is inimical to our individual liberty. The point is that all mail-in voting would eliminate the last monitored and equally accessible polling places, where poll watchers and (mostly) non-partisan volunteers see that voting is done fairly and accurately.  In its place would spring up all kinds of potentially coercive or at least unduly influential situations in which voting would occur, without monitoring of any kind.  There is also the 'lost in the mail,' the 'signature didn't match' and the spoiled ballot without chance to even know it...circumstances inherent in that system.

Comment: "John North, the vice president of finance for Ashland-based Lithia Motors, said the auto retailer would see almost all its profits from Oregon stores wiped out under a tax measure headed toward the November 2016 ballot.

"That's not really sustainable," said North, adding that Lithia, one of the state's three Fortune 500 companies, might reduce its presence in Oregon if the measure passes.

"Everything is on the table," he said.  "We may have to change our headquarters."

North said his firm now pays between $3 million and $4 million a year in state taxes, and he calculates that amount would increase to about $35 million. Lithia operates on an after-tax margin of about 2.7 percent, he said, and a sales-based tax of 2.5 percent "basically takes away all the motivation to do business in Oregon because there is no profit."

Comment: "Eugene, Oregon, violent crime, on a scale from 1 (low crime) to 100, is 21. Violent crime is composed of four offenses: murder and nonnegligent manslaughter, forcible rape, robbery, and aggravated assault. The US average is 31.1. Eugene, Oregon, property crime, on a scale from 1 (low) to 100, is 60. Property crime includes the offenses of burglary, larceny-theft, motor vehicle theft, and arson. The object of the theft-type offenses is the taking of money or property, but there is no force or threat of force against the victims. The US average is 38.1."  From Sperlings best places:  
Portland's numbers are 43 and 62 respectively.  Roseburg's are 17 and 73.  Coos Bay's are 34 and and 67.  So using police department statistics as rated by an unbiased agency (Sperlings Best Places), "Eugene is clearly NOT the most dangerous city in Oregon...in terms of violent crime it's safer than Portland and Coos Bay and only slightly more dangerous than Roseburg.  Gary Crum

Comment: Airlines are complex, challenging and often marginally profitable enterprises. Few of them rate outstanding with customers; hard to do while keeping costs down and travel affordable. 

All things considered however, discount airlines WestJet comes out well above Air Canada on most customer criteria. Anyone who flies regularly is well aware that attitudes at Air Canada are anything but consistent. Sure some are good but far too many - especially older employees - exhibit a take or leave it attitude. WestJet staff are more friendly and accommodating. The main difference, of course, is that one is unionized and the other (so far) is not. WestJet has managed to stave it off by offering competitive pay and benefits. 

Unions make great sense in manufacturing and heavy industry. But they don't work well in the service sector - and especially not in the travel and tourism industries. This WestJet pilot showed initiative and sensitivity rarely seen at Air Canada. My compliments!

He was of his grandfather's time, no doubt. Kind of glad he doesn't teach at the UofO, all in all. 
Sure, in the (American) Founders' time there was a need for hard edged thinking that told all Americans work or die, find your plot of land and make something of yourself. No one owed you anything because the jobs were there, as were the acres. Who needed health care? 
However, this ain't that time. In my far right New Hampshire Republican Grandfather's world, hippies were to be shot on sight, a comment I heard him make. His town had a large manufacturing base. Then that base moved, as did the hopes of many that the America dream was possible for them.
Knox was a creature of his time, and like my grandfather, not one one would hope to reason with.

Hugh Massengill, Eugene Oregon

Comment: That is a broad and sweeping claim. I do not deny that some of the most vocal supporters of the Extraordinary Form do advocate for the repeal of V2. On the other hand, I have heard many Catholics who deride the Latin Mass and those who prefer it. For them it's about getting rid of everything *before* V2. Before Summorum Pontificum (and still, to an extent, after) priests who wished to celebrate the Extraordinary Form were often met with nothing but road blocks and derision. The problem exists on both "sides". But I have found most people take a more nuanced view. I know many people who attend both the Extraordinary and the Ordinary Form regularly. The primary concern of many more traditionally minded Catholics is that the (T/t)raditions of the Roman Rite are upheld and preserved (and this must, by default, include the ancient and venerable Extraordinary Form), and that, as MSW writes above, the Mass is celebrated well.

Comment: So, Neko, I tend to agree with your assessment of the status quo. But what would happen if we all backed away from the table one step and rethought our assumptions? It might look something like this.
1. Stakeholder #1: the fetus will continue to term unless there is an intervention. Therefore, we may say that the fetus "prefers" to continue the pregnancy and will not/cannot take a different initiative that affects the ethical outcome. (A spontaneous abortion is not an initiative.)
2. Stakeholder #2: the woman is subject to conflicting forces, some of which incline her to carry the fetus to term and some of which incline her to terminate the pregnancy.  Since the actual decision is eventually hers, the question is whether the negative factors can (or should be) neutralized.
3. Stakeholder #3: family/society are also conflicted about the pregnancy, desiring to support both fetus and woman. The questions is whether family/society can resolve the conflicts. (More after dinner is cooked...)

Comment: We can replace the broken panes with replicas made by a talented craftsman, but don't anyone succumb to the notion that doing so makes everything right.  The originals were part of Hawaii's cultural history.

Like the priceless archaeological sites and artifacts systematically destroyed by ISIS in Iraq or the statues of the Buddha dynamited by the Taliban in Afghanistan, replicas can be newly made at great expense, or similar pieces borrowed from foreign museums, but it doesn't change the fact that irreplaceable parts of our human heritage are lost forever.

Using an example all of us can wrap our heads around, suppose some maniac stormed the Louvre and detonated a powerful bomb right next to the Mona Lisa, reducing it to smithereens.  Now sure, the painting has been digitally scanned six ways from Sunday, and we could with a lot of effort make a facsimile indistinguishable from the original.  But would you feel the same emotional pull or wonder from a replica no matter how well made?

Comment: Measure 97's nonsensical drafting makes it probably the most unfair and regressive taxes considered in Oregon for many years. It raises taxes by 500 percent over what all corporations paid in Oregon income taxes last year, then targets a small number of corporation to pay the whole thing. It takes the entire profits of many retailers such as grocers, auto dealers, and big retailers like Costco, Fred Meyer, and Walmart, and Walgreens, forcing them to raise prices on consumer essentials like groceries and medicine.

The non-partisan Legislative Revenue Office estimates middle income Oregonians will pay $600 - $800 more per year in increased prices, with no exemptions for essentials. This is regressive taxation at its worst.

Comment: As an Oregonian, I voted against the GMO labeling because I believed  that:

 "There is a general scientific agreement that food from genetically modified crops is not inherently riskier to human health than conventional food, but should be tested on a case-by-case basis".

And that "No reports of ill effects have been proven in the human population from ingesting GM food."

When I voted that way, I was aware that: 

"The Organic Consumers Association, and the Union of Concerned Scientists and Greenpeace stated that risks have not been adequately identified and managed, and they have questioned the objectivity of regulatory authorities. Some health groups say there are unanswered questions regarding the potential long-term impact on human health from food derived from GMOs."

Having said all that, if it makes people happier to have a label that says "GMO" on it, the label shouldn't be hidden in smartphone gobbledygook or require calling a 1-800 number.

Comment: OrsonW

Your post is misleading. 

Mexico's total number of murders may be the second highest in the world, but expressed as the standard 'per 100,000' it is far from second. Population data for Mexico will be reliable. 

Mexico's 'intentional homicide' rate is 15.7 per 100,000.  In comparison here are some other numbers;

Belize 34.4
US Virgin Islands 52.6
Puerto Rico 18.5
Saint Kitts and Nevis 33.6
Saint Lucia 21.6
Jamaica 36.1
Bahamas 29.8

and one of my favorite places

Cuba 4.2

I was in Mexico just before Christmas and never once felt in danger.  When traveling anywhere common sense has to prevail.  Yes, Mexico has a drug 'war' going on, but this is occurring only in certain areas of the country. These areas are well known, avoid them.

Comment: "...an eddy moving through the islands raises sea levels."

I'm pretty well-read on meteorologic phenomena, but an ocean eddy that can anomalously raise sea level locally by a foot is a new one on me.  I did some googling and understand ocean eddies better now, but the difference in sea level between adjacent areas of the ocean seems to be what PRODUCES eddies, not the RESULT of an eddy.  

Or alternatively, eddies form as a result of oceanographic features such as islands and then migrate downcurrent, much like what happens downstream of rocks in rivers.  That seems most unlikely in this case because there are no other islands within thousands of miles of us and this one is described as "moving through" our islands rather than having been generated by them.

Anyone who can help me sort this out, your info would be much appreciated.

Comment: The NTSB is absolutely correct here. Years ago they wouldn't say anything about an accident until the final analysis was out. They learned that releasing bits of pertinent information had the potential of creating earlier awareness to situations that might contribute to accidents. It is obviously not legitimate to draw premature conclusions, such as "pilot error", on the other hand it is equally unreasonable to censor dialogue on these accidents by both the aviation community and the public at large.

Speculation was negligent maintenance. The accident came up at our coffee gathering, one pilot blew his top, as he knew the mechanic and didn't want someone knocking his friend with rumor. Later, it was confirmed that the mechanic had reversed cables. Unfortunately, between the time it was made official and public another identical accident occurred and that pilot also died. I strongly believe that the second reversal might not have occurred if the first was widely publicized.

Comment: In a time when economic inequality has never been higher, Oregonians need to thank their lucky stars that we have never authorized a sales tax. We have great potential to be progressive, not regressive, by reforming BOTH the corporate income tax and the personal income tax. Until millionaires have a tax rate that is significantly higher than someone making $20,000 per year, a sales tax, or its evil twin, the gross revenue tax, makes no sense.

And as far as stability of tax revenue is concerned, all tax receipts will plunge when the next economic downturn occurs, including sales and gross receipts taxes. Stable tax revenue is a pipe dream, but is being hyped as a way to make the gross receipts tax seem more palatable.

No matter how they structure the gross receipts tax, it will pick winners and losers. They could have 20 tax rates (see Washington) and it would still tax some businesses more heavily than others. And it is wide-open to lobbying every session (again, see Washington).

Comment: Hello, 
Where did you get this evidence? Which TB test are you referring to? I work as a nurse and I routinely administer and interpret the Mantoux TB skin test. So, I will have to disagree with you that this does not exist. Also, the Mantoux test only tests for exposure to TB, not active disease. A chest radiograph would provide evidence of the latter - and would thus differentiate between latent TB and active TB.

Comment: The no-fly list should be abolished. The description of the people on the list, "too dangerous to fly, but too innocent to jail", is inherently self-contradictory. If there is good reason to suspect a person of nefarious intent, I can see putting them on an "enhanced security" list, but without PROOF of guilt sufficient to justify jailing them, it's a clear-cut violation of individual rights and freedoms to go any further than that. 

Also, anybody who is to be put on the enhanced security list should be notified that is being done and offered a court hearing at which the government has the burden of proving that they belong on the list.

Comment: Hello Rich,

I spend a great deal of time in both countries. 

I was 23 when Nixon resigned. The whole process took years and took more TV time than anything in my lifetime except, perhaps, the O J Simpson case.

When TV entered everyones home in the 1960s and early 1970s it acted in a way that established a great deal of prestige for the press. This reached its zenith about 1975 and the press was respected and trusted.

In retrospect, it was at this time that the press had the power to topple an administration and decided to do so.

I think that is no longer true.

In the time since, the press in the US has lost a great deal of  power. I believe that it is now the least trusted institution in the US, well below Trump. They are destroying their last bit of credibility with the public attacking Trump.

Americans no longer have years of patience. They are already beginning to tune out news on Trump. This will come to a conclusion soon or the public will turn on those reporting on it.

Comment: An idiotic comment. We cannot boost any economy with waste and environmental destruction. BC Hydro's residential, commercial and industrial customers used less electricity in 2016 than in 2005, according to the utility's own records. BC can create yet more reductions in electricity consumption easily by investing in more efficient motors and lighting. In addition, solar power can be generated on utility scale at far less than what Site C will cost. Alberta created power capacity at Shepard Energy Centre at $1.75 million per MW. Site C will cost $8-10 million per MW. That means we won't be selling expensive power to our neighbours. Nor will we sell surpluses to California where they are closing power stations because conservation is happening through modern technologies.  If the only reason to build Site C is to create jobs, we'll create more jobs by building it with picks, shovels and hand labour. That would employ more people.

Comment: "Instead of attacking “outside” commenters who correct your misinformation, why don’t you address the comments we place?"

I've looked at all the comments discussing you outsiders, and for the life of me, I can't see where we've attacked you.  We've simply been discussing the fact that you exist, and that you dominate the discussion of this article.  

As to addressing your comments ...  there are clearly facts on both sides (calm down, now), and I have never made any claim to be an expert.  But I can read, and I am pretty good at logic, so I have an opinion.  First Amendment, even if you don't like my opinion.

I happen to take the European approach  --  where there is a possibility of harm, we should refrain from acting.  Clearly, you take the opposite approach:  where there is a possibility of good, we should act.  

A case can be made for both.  But it doesn't need to be made over and over, nor to drown out local discussion of local issues.

Comment: They do, actually. I work in the Northwest Territories. All children born here receive the BCG vaccine (or maybe all aboriginal children, I'm not sure). Pretty much all of my patients have the scar to prove it. If we have to send a mother to Edmonton to deliver her baby for some reason, the baby will not receive the BCG vaccine. My understanding is that it is not routinely given in Alberta (as per their provincial formulary), therefore the nurses are not trained to administer it, and it has to given very quickly after birth so by the time they come back up north, its too late to receive it. 

So my point is that most individuals in this territory are vaccinated. I'm not familiar with Nunavut's policies. And I'm not familiar with the efficacy of that vaccine.

Comment: Well written, Charles, and points up a huge part of the issue. We need to stop saying "the homeless" as if their circumstances are meaningfully alike except the most superficial of "not having regular housing," and we definitely need to stop using children and the financially unlucky as the sympathetic face of that superficial description.

We cannot efficiently and effectively allocate our limited resources until we start describing the various subsets of the issue with precision. Elders who are homeless have different needs than teen runaways. "Sane" but chronic public inebriates (alcoholics and drug abusers) different needs than the incompetent mentally ill who self-medicate with drugs and alcohol. Competent and physically-able but shiftless drifters and criminals, often driven from their home towns due to their deliberate actions, require different responses by different public services than those few families in dire financial straits due to unforeseeable tragedy. We need honesty.

Comment: This is about tribal membership and jurisdiction over members , not some larger notion of how much Native one might be and whether a tribe could reach out and take over jurisdiction of a non-enrolled child.
Under federal law tribes determine by explicit rules who may be enrolled in their tribe.
"... tribal nations use a variety of criteria in determining their membership. These tools may be used in combination as well. For example, many tribes who use descendancy may also use blood quantum defined in terms of either tribal blood or Indian blood.  Others will combine parental residency requirements with descendancy."
http://genetics.ncai.org/tribal-sovereignty-and-enrollment-determinations.cfm
This does all get sticky when a child is an enrolled member and a parent is not. Though there is some case law which addresses the rights of that parent  , much is still being duked out there.

Comment: Cruise terminals cost money to build.  Revenue needs to pay for the cost.  The list of activities is call marketing.  Revenue pays for marketing.  The kickback is called a commission and is the source of the revenue.  If you don't want to pay for the terminal and marketing, you don't have to; but you loose out of the captive market and you loose out of the net 70-75%.  I sell a local service and pay a commission (or as you refer, a kickback) for the marketing and admin.  It is well worth it.  The locals will benefit from a larger customer base brought in by the cruise line.

Comment: I don't think this will be material on the true 'small' business owner, since the costs of accounting for small incomes and managing to defer tax aren't likely worth the gains because their marginal tax rates are also low.  
The greatest pushback (and likely most organized and vocal lobby) will come from those with the most to lose.  They can afford the accounting, and access the specialized products to make them count to reduce taxes.  From expensing large UL policies which include cash savings that can be withdrawn tax free, to deducting vacations, they benefit vs. a similarly paid employee in a very material way.  As a result, higher income earners are growing ever more likely to change business structures to gain from less tax.  
My brother lives in Calgary, and his oil company employer laid him off, paid for his accounting to set up his company, and worked through a complex array of compensation.  End result, less cost for oilco, more cash for him, paid for by less tax for society

Comment: Non sequitur: The Church may very well have received magisterial authority from Christ; but even if Christ "cannot err" (which btw has to be demonstrated; you seem to take it as axiomatic), it does not follow that the Church cannot err -- unless you wish to assert that with the authority to teach comes all the content of any future teaching, a bizarre shift in the meaning of "authority."

As for slavery, etc., whatever you wish to say about "Christ Himself," the historical Jesus was an apocalyptic prophet, who expected the eschaton after only a brief wait, and so was not interested in reforming society, as though society was expected to persist for a long time. There were all kinds of subjects, ethical and other, about which he had little or no interest. So to assign to "Christ Himself" direct authority for teachings and judgments that Christians later devised for themselves, however fine, is fanciful and fictitious: defensible perhaps, but hardly to be imposed as a criterion.

Comment: IMHO, both yes and no. 

Yes, the scientific method brilliantly actualizes the innate structure of the human mind  which Bernard Lonergan (Insight, Study of Human Understanding) elaborates as the three levels of consciousness involved in knowing. On the first level (Experience) we are merely aware of data; on the second level (Understanding) we have insights into that data, generating hypotheses, understandings, ideas that might explain the data of Experience; and on the third level (Judgement) we evaluate the understandings, hypothesis, theories generated on the second level with a view to determining which, if any, might be true or more probable. 

Science limits the data it considers to the external data of sense, but we also have internal data, data about our own inner, subjective experiences. The humanities in general consider this inner data as well as external data; and mystic discernment involves striving to understand that component of the internal data caused by the Spirit.

Comment: We can expect to receive at least 30% less rain. Considering that we're already a "dry" area, I think it's reasonable to regard "30% less rain" as a permanent state of dryness. We need to plan for regular shortages, and we need to adapt our behaviour to show much more respect for water than we have until now. The City has taken it for granted that a water shortage at the end of summer is no big deal, because winter will provide, but climate change has already had a significant effect on CT - we no longer have a Mediterranean climate. When my mother grew up here, winter rains meant two weeks of solid drizzle, then a day or two of clear weather, then two weeks of solid drizzle, etc - right through winter. I've lived in CT for about 30 years, and I've never seen that. We're now getting rain much later in winter, and much less of it, and we're getting the odd storm right into November. Overall, we're getting much less water out of the sky, so we have to be much smarter about how we use it.

Comment: An  interesting  analysis  but  simplistic  to  look  at  annual consumption  and  theoretical  production  numbers  and  say  voila,  it  is  done.

Hydro  sources  come  with  their  own  set  of  environmental  issues,  consider  Site  C  and  Muskrat  Falls.  Solar  and  wind  power  are  intermittent  and  require  on line  backup.  On  an  annual  basis  solar  potential  may  exceed  demand  yet  many  provinces  have  their  peak  electricity  demand  during  winter  evenings  when  there  is  no  solar  power  available.

The  authors  can  advance  their  study  by  re-examining  their  numbers  in  consideration  of  seasonal  and  day  to  night  variations.

There  is  no  doubt  there  is  more  potential  for  renewable  energy  production.  Some  day  it  will  be  cheaper  than  alternatives   (perhaps  we  should  wait  for  that  day  before  construction).  The  day  where  Canada consumes  energy  solely  from  renewable  sources  is  far, far  in  the  future.

Hard to imagine in what respect your friend thinks courts would be better.

Human rights tribunals have changed immensely, in Ontario almost 10 years ago. They now operate in quite a similar matter to courts.  In Quebec, human rights cases are heard by a panel of three, one of whom is a judge of the Quebec Court who acts full-time on the Human Rights Tribunal.  The other two are not judges, but lawyers.

By the way, the vast majority of legal cases in Canada are heard by tribunals, not courts.

Comment: Thank you for your reflections about your experience at Christmas time.  Christmas does seem to be a time for reflection on the passing of time and of persons.  When my siblings and I were young, there were thirty-four persons, counting our parents, in the generation just above ours.  As I entered my forties, I was aware that that generation was aging and passing; when my mother died a few years ago, they were all gone; and my siblings and cousins have taken their place: we're the older generation, and some of us are gone, too.  It's important to appreciate each other while we can, to tell the stories, to record them and pass them down.  I love the genealogies of Jesus that we find in Matthew and Luke, because they convey the importance of family and roots.

Comment: The tax department did not approve anything.  That's not what advanced tax rulings are.

Advanced tax rulings are confirmations from Revenue Canada of an interpretation of tax laws.   In the advanced ruling, Revenue Canada concurred with the Bronfmans reading of the tax laws at that time.  That was done under the Mulroney Conservative government.  Subsequent Chrétien Liberal government asked CRA to examine the situation again and the conclusion was also the same.

In Federal Court case Harris v. Canada, a federal judge looked into allegations of bad faith and preferential treatment in giving that advanced tax ruling to the Bronfmans.  Judge found the accusations to be unsubstantiated.

I think you are confusing legal tax avoidance with illegal tax evasion.  As far I'm concerned, there is no tax gap from people who legally avoid taxes with RRSP, TFSA, and even family trusts.

Comment: The land at the main trail head down below was part of the former USCG station which, under federal law, was conveyed to DHHL around 2000. 

It's a major white elephant for DHHL because it's useless for their primary mission, which does NOT include managing  dangerous tourist attractions. Can't blame them for not wanting to deal with the Stairs. 

The reality is no private entity could own/manage the Stairs because the liability is too great; it's also very doubtful that they could generate enough income to keep the Stairs in good repair, pay for liability insurance, etc.  As noted in the article, no other government agency (like CCH's Parks & Rec or DLNR) has stepped up to take over so there aren't many realistic alternatives. 

Again, running tourist attractions is NOT the job of BWS and I, as a ratepayer, do not blame them for trying to get rid of the Stairs, one way or another.  In fact, I applaud them for finally dealing with the issue.

Comment: The only horror stories that are runner-up to the amount of ones about horrible tenants are the ones of horrible property managers. Property managers hardly ever "prove their value."
.

.

Comment: In the 1840's, the Franklin expedition was the equivalent of the 1960's Apollo moon program,  it was the moon-shot of its day.  2 ships and 129 men with the most advanced technology of the time leaving the known world into the unknown.  Unfortunately, they succumbed to scurvy, starvation and lead poisoning caused by poorly soldered and cheap canned food. The food provisioner in London used lead to solder the inside seams of the cans to seal them, contaminating the contents.  The Royal Navy contracted the cheapest food supplier they could find and never even inspected the product or the facility where it was being produced.  "Frozen in Time: The Fate of the Franklin Expedition" by by Owen Beattie and John Geiger is an excellent book on the subject.  They applied modern forensic techniques to discover the likely cause of the expedition's demise.

Comment: Actually, the original CFLs were terrible on the eyes, which is the only thing that matters when talking about the light in a home.  People tried them and then never tried again even though they got better.  I hated the cold light and never used them except in spaces I rarely went into (like the crawl space).  Warm LEDs have won me over - but when considering the light in my home, there are many things more important than efficiency - and I suspect I am in a comfortable majority here.  We'd all love to be more eco friendly but the cost cannot be our mental well being - cold light will never feel right no matter how eco friendly it is.  There are other things that fall into this category - just because something is "good for you" does not mean you will embrace it, it must be as good as what is being replaced for wide spread adoption to happen.

Comment: I agree children should have sunscreen, ear protection & water, but the reasons you give for not bringing your children do not apply to a nursing infant. The presence of drunk & stoned fans will not make an impression on a baby. It's entirely possible that the sleep schedule of an infant actually fits fine with an evening game, and afternoon games are done by dinnertime, hardly a late hour for any child.

Nursing mothers & their babies are often more comfortable together than apart. The mother of your child can explain why. She can also enlighten you on why a mom who has no hungry baby available will welcome a private comfy spot to pump and still have a chance to use their season tickets. Yes, really.

I would not personally bring a child to an NFL stadium, but that's my decision. As long as someone protects their baby's skin and hearing, attends to physical needs &  doesn't allow them to disturb others, there's no reason to judge that decision or call them selfish.

Comment: I've been a fan of Trevor's but it's time to make a change.  He's a solid QB when the rest of the offense is going well.  But when the protection is weak, and the running game is getting stuffed, Trevor just doesn't have the strengths to help make up for those other deficiencies on O.  A double-threat QB that can take off and scramble when protection breaks down can help counter the pass rush, but Trevor is weak on scrambling ability. He also stays locked into a receiver too much, and is slow to read and react.  

Unfortunately our other QBs may not be much better in those areas.  But at this point I think we just need to make the change, because this combination clearly isn't working.  The main problem remains the bad OL, of course, but we're pretty much stuck there.  At QB we can make a change.  I'd give Oz the start for the next few games.  If he does well, great, but if not, Paxton should be healed enough next month to take over for the rest of the season as his (final) test.

Comment: When a financial "expert" flunks even the most basic premise of compound interest, any advice given becomes highly suspect. A cap of 20% after five years does not represent 4% annually, it is 3.71% compounded annually, or less than the dividend of the typical bank stock. Just think of the Rule-Of-72, where a 6% gain annually does not mean 72% after twelve years, but a doubling of the original investment.

Mr. Berman also fails to mention that the fine print means that this cap applies to every holding in the PPN, so every individual one is capped at a max rate of 4%. So, there's no cushion for an outperformer to make up for a laggard, and the weaker ones will further reduce the gross return below the 4% ceiling for the whole PPN.

Many PPNs also include a clause regarding an unspecified "negative event" which will completely disable any growth for the entire PPN, yielding nothing more than the guaranteed 2% (or less). Who writes the rules, why the provider, of course.

Humbug!!!

Comment: My father loved collecting Canadian antiquities, and there is even a WW1 medal among the items. He learned very quickly about sellers remorse, tho not from the seller but rather their kids who had NEVER shown an interest in the items until they were told they were sold. Then the seller would call, sheepishly asking for them back.
From this he learned to always document where and who everything came from and get a bill of sale.  When he passed away, his obit wasn't two days old before my mother began getting calls asking for items back, one person even suggesting their item was stolen.  We simply went to his big binder of receipts and read off the date and name of the seller, and never heard from these people again.

An inscribed medal is a silly thing to try to steal and fence - after all it has the owner's name on it! I think it's everyone's assumption that Grandad would never get rid of his medals/family heirlooms, but 99% of the time that is wrong.  What we value changes with time.

Comment: The idea of increased interest rates is to curb spending by the consumer and thus reduce demand for goods. Suppliers would then be forced to keep prices low, in order to keep sales volumes up. Manufacturing is more efficient when volumes are high. However, a manufacturer can only go down to cost and if it is a listed company, its share price will drop if it does not declare profits, so it has to cut costs, either by selling of capacity in a market where there is surplus capacity, or by cutting labour costs. Jobs. The increase in the repo rate thus not only did NOT contain price increases, but also reduced employment. The increases in controlled prices have a far greater impact on consumer spending than the actions of the SARB. The repo rate also has very little impact on the spending patterns of the poor. They buy food, pay rent, which is not determined by interest rates, and use public transport, mostly taxis, where another controlled price, fuel has a major impact. Cont..

I disagree about dropping the ADN -- it needs all of our support right now.

Comment: In BC we have language diversity options.  In the school system you have  selections for the second language option, unlike the French only I faced many years ago.

Now it is French, Spanish,  Japanese, or Mandarin. In fact early Mandarin or Mandarin immersion programs are becoming more popular. A nod to the changing demographics here, and where business and trade opportunities lie in the future.

As someone who has raised kids in the Richmond system, to be honest much of the popularity of French immersion programs here were for the most part as their school within a school concept.  

They did not have to accept children with ESL challenges, or  more severe learning disabilities. The French Immersion program was perceived as being exclusionary, thus having an  educational advantage over classrooms where half the kids struggled with speaking English or had special needs.

It was very little to do with parents wanting their kids to have some sort of "distinct Canadian" education.

Comment: With respect, while they have botched this file, it is relatively unimportant.
.
The biggest political issue in Ontario, by far, is congestion.
It is a 90-minute-per-day tax on everyone, and eveything.
It is a tax on every business trying to deliver its products, or dependent upon receiving parts or services from suppliers.
.
The congestion tax is enormous.
It is orders of magnitude larger than the cost of electricity.
It is the largest single tax we pay, other than income tax.
.
On congestion, there just isn't any choice.
.
The Conservatives represent the oil companies, who profit from everybody being stuck in traffic burning gas.  Conservatives hate transit.  Conservatives kill transit.
.
The NDP, the supposed party of the working man, you'd think, is strangely unhelpful on transit.
.
Which leaves Kathleen Wynne: The only lifetime transit rider in the bunch.
Whatever you may say about her, she understands the need for transit, now.
That is all that matters.
.
She is the only choice.

Comment: “Trump encourages Russia to spy on Clinton”

No. People are being mislead by terrible journalism.

1. If Russia is not already spying on the secretary of state of their largest geopolitical rival, then they are the stupidest superpower in world history. They don’t need Trump’s “encouragement.”

2. Trump is not “encouraging” Russia to hack into Clinton’s email server. Trump is (correctly) noting that they have almost certainly already hacked it and is encouraging Russia to release what they found.

3. Clinton’s lawyers and aides deleted almost 30,000 emails – and wiped their hard drives – before turning the rest over to investigators. They claimed that these 30,000 were not work-related. However, FBI investigators were able to recover some of the 30,000, and discovered that, yes, some of them were in fact work-related.

4. So that is what Trump is saying: Hopefully, Russia will produce what Clinton’s team deleted.

5. I despise Trump. For the record.

Comment: The problem with ACA is cost.  It has no controls on the payments demanded for medical treatment.  It is unsustainable and ultimately will bankrupt the nation.  Yes, single-payer health care is the way to go.  Single payer with that single payer setting firm limits on the amounts that the medical industry can charge.  Couple that to substantially increased enrollments at medical, nursing, and dental schools and then we can have universal coverage and truly affordable care.  The ACA itself cannot survive long.  Take a look at the projected budget deficit in Oregon.  A good part of that is due to the expansion of Oregon's medicaid under the ACA, which the feds are no longer paying for.  Obamacare only included heavy federal subsidy until Obama left office.  Convenient?  Unfortunately, the medical and insurance industries will declare war on the rest of us and any associated politicians to prevent such a program.

This invariably leads to the cop asking me if I have a gun now.  If I do, I tell him so and where it is, carefully keeping my hands glued to the steering wheel.  After that, it's a simple matter of following instructions carefully.  No more; no less.

Castile's inability to follow instructions, I believe, directly led to his death.

Comment: A 2003 legislative earmark gave the Alaska Native community at Adak Island (and thereby Adak Fisheries) exclusive rights to pollock fishing, worth millions of dollars to Adak Fisheries. Beginning in July 2002, Ben Stevens held a secret option, expiring in December 2004, to buy a 25% ownership in Adak for an immediate payment of $50,000 and another $450,000 paid over time. In mid-2004, 50% of Adak was sold for $4.3 million to a Seattle company. Adak Fisheries paid Stevens $295,000 between 2000 and 2004. The Aleut Corporation attorney, Roger DuBrock, said in a deposition, "My concern is that if it ever became public knowledge that Sen. Ted Stevens got legislation passed for a pollock allocation that ended up getting assigned to Adak Fisheries, and that Ben Stevens, his son, had an ownership interest in that company, there would be all kinds of unfavorable newspaper reports written that might damage Senator Stevens and might damage Ben Stevens and might damage the Aleut Corporation."

Comment: Before the MarineMammal Protecton Act, I consumed polar bear meat on numerous occasions. It was usually boiled, then dipped in seal oil (from oogruks -the best). While assisting other guides on hunts, I always brought in at least the hams & gave a lot away to friends & neighbors in Kotzebue. One evening, at a gathering of hunters & peripheral folks, an inebriated taxidermist from Spokane berated me for bringing in meat.  The slurry-speached fellow suggested I enjoy some liver, & bet me $500 that I would not. So I said, "Its a bet, then"  He said I should show up with cash as I would be dead before he could cash a check. We shook hands, with witnesses.
So the next evening he showed up with a large lobe of pb liver. We each showed our cash. I fried up a sliver of liver, & ate it. He protested, I bet on eating pb liver -not a WHOLE liver. After 2 hours of drinking & grousing, he handed over the $500. I suffered not at all, bought a new SnoJet for $600, laughed my way home.

Comment: I would never make light of alcoholism in the priesthood, which is, as you say, a very real problem, just as I wouldn't make light of the very real dangers of drug abuse. 

The issue is the double standard that says recreational alcohol is fine but recreational marijuana isn't. The only difference, as far as I can tell, is that alcohol is an acceptable part of our culture -- especially within Catholicism -- and pot isn't. When abused, both substances can be destructive.

If the bishops want to teach about the virtues of moderation and temperance, I fully support them. But when they stray into trying to influence public policy on marijuana while fostering a culture of recreational use of alcohol, they lose me.

 It looks like a herd of goats fed on anything they can reach, but no, it's humans.  They stripped the area and left their waste and their trash.

They drove their trucks with their multi-vehicle trailers to the trailheads and unloaded their machines so they could ride to the campsites.

Real outdoorsmen.

Comment: There is nothing wrong with a stronger dollar, even a currency at par with the US dollar. But it needs to be when the Canadian economy is thriving. The complaints now made against the current situation are because (a) the economy is not on a strong footing (b) the manufacturing sector is suffering (c) household debt is at record levels with Canadians owing $2 trillion (d) unemployment at 6.6% is unacceptable (e) inflation at 1.01% is virtually non-existent (f) GDP while satisfactory did not reach analysts' expectations in the first quarter and (g) exports in the first the quarter slipped to an annualized rate of 1.3 per cent.
A stronger dollar? When the boat is sinking the wise captain plugs the holes and levels the craft. A stronger dollar should be accompanied by a gradually improving economy so that everything rises in tandem. A recovery cannot be lopsided. Everything must tick in unison.

Comment: Again, I have to differ.  A street check, as we call it in the West, does have a salutatory effect. If I check you and your crew hanging out in a park at 2 am, I know who you associate with.  Then, should I arrest you for a robbery (purse snatching), and the guy you were with matches the description of one of your friends I checked you with last week, I know the other suspect. 

 Now, I fully support your position that you and your friends don't have to identify yourselves, unless I can articulate a reason to detain you.  But, that does not mean I don't have the right to at least stop and speak with you.  And, that is what I think Desmond Cole would like to change; the ability of the police to stop, and speak in a civil manner, to any person/groups that they feel may be of interest.  

 Missing in Cole's analogy is the context of the neigbhourhoods, the crime patterns and the fact that street people are victimized by other street people.  Who looks after them, if not the police?

Comment: Pat, Pat, Pat.  Of all the life choices affecting one's physical and emotional well being, there is none with greater ramifications for good or ill than the selection of parents. Why on earth should the wider society, so well stocked with people who exercised good judgement at that vital juncture, treating it with the sober reflection and analysis that it requires, bear any responsibility for those who failed in their own due diligence? 

Can't you see how this would set up a counter-incentive? What point would there be for us in choosing healthy parents, if we are to be saddled caring for those who didn't, regardless? If we're going to be taxed regardless of our probity, why bother screening our parents for pattern-baldness, MS, social advantage, and all the rest?  Why wouldn't we all just say, "Responsibility be damned! I'm going to spend my brief life wallowing in diseases beyond my means!" Answer me that. Hrumph. The importance of personal responsibility cannot be overstated.

Comment: The main problem is the investigations costs. The Board most likely has no control over who is hired and what they are paid, the state Division of Corporations, Business and Professional Licensing controls that part. The licensee gets the bill. This had been a huge problem with other Boards as well. Bad accounting and little oversight or accountability has been systematic. Some investigations cost a Board over $30,000 and produce let's say a $5000 fine.  But the fine does not go to the Board, it goes to the State. In many cases the licensee that is being investigated by the Dept. has already been convicted and fined in criminal court. So how does the State spend $30,000 to investigate something that has already been investigated and facts determined, tried and convicted. The system is being milked to the point of potential fraud. It seems close to double jeopardy but one is criminal court and the other civil court. The costs to benefits are questionable or negative.

Comment: Discussion of gravity waves has been ongoing for many decades.  Gravity waves are similar in concept to electromagnetic waves, i.e. radio, light, X-rays, etc.  Gravity, however, is much weaker than electromagnetic forces.  Just as electric current moving back and forth in an antenna creates radio waves, objects moving around each other in orbits emit gravitational waves.  Because gravity is so much weaker than electromagnetic forces, it takes truly massive objects to make gravitational waves we can detect.  Everybody expected gravitational waves to exist, the challenge was to make a receiver sensitive enough to detect them.  Basically no practical importance as far as human existence is concerned.  However, the detection of the gravitational waves is a brilliant feat of experimental physics.

Comment: A few things to consider for anyone in their position: 

1. You may not have the child when you expect or not at all and may need fertility treatments that cost a lot of money
2. Make sure you have adequate disability and life insurance -both private and don't rely on work related insurance alone. 
3. Maximize your accident benefits- the likelihood of an accident with commuting is likely higher than those that don't rely on vehicles to get to work. You will eat through the current standard benefits in no time and will pay out of pocket for the rest
4. Spending on entertainment etc seems pretty extravagant.
5. Cut back on expenses where you can and build a rainy day fund, you never know when you might need it.
6. A job loss can happen to anyone at any time and with it goes, the pension. 
7. If you have to be working at 2 jobs each just to make ends meet, it suggests you are not living within your means.
8. Its good to start thinking of retirement, but a lot can change from age 29-60.

Comment: "moral theology flows from catholic social justice theory - not the other way around and moral theology does not come first."

Citation needed.

Moral theology is based on applying systematic theology to what man has to do to achieve ultimate beatitude. Social justice is part of that as it is part of the virtue of justice as it specifically applies to distributive justice, but all that is a subcategory of moral theology. To claim moral theology flows from catholic social justice theory is like saying the earth sciences flow from geophysics.

I think what is going on is that "Social Justice Catholics" are often accused of moral relativism. This is because they often come to the same conclusions as moral relativists. But the charge of relativism is false, as the reason why they come to those conclusions is because they are over emphasizing a small slice of Catholic teaching to the point it eclipses other de fide teaching.

Comment: As several other posters have suggested already, the article's thesis seems fatuous:  As mass shootings can always be expected to induce terror, we can therefore suppose the inducement of terror to be inherent in the motivation of the crime, which renders pointless any attempt to distinguish one case from another in terms of motivation.   Well why stop there?  As death is invariably the result of homicide, why trouble ourselves with distinctions between spontaneous and premeditated, etc. -- the victims are equally dead in any case.  And what of 'hate crimes'?  Aren't those by definition determined by motivation?  In fact the law is continually making determinations of culpability and degree based on the motive of the offender.  So why try to claim here that it's irrelevant?  Other than as a dodge or damage control, that is.

Hugh Massengill, Eugene

Comment: "We will never know how many air crashes are the result of intoxicated pilots because there is not much left to examine after they crash. "

This claim is false. It's extremely rare that the authorities can't test for substances in the pilot after an aircraft accident. Only the most isolated of incidents leave the authorities with nothing to test. In every other incident, the pilot survives or pilot remains are available for testing. Comment: Any money you put it, you get back out when you sell.
If you buy this $86k place and do a $400k reno, the house will be worth $486k (and likely more due to sweat equity) so if you sell it that's what you get back.
The /only/ difference between the setup on the island and the rest of Toronto is that there is no bidding war, and the price is set via appraisal - not by what the owner thinks it's worth.  

So no speculation, no flipping, no overheated market - the house is worth what it's actually worth, and nothing more.
Make sense?  It's actually an awesome system if y'all stop freaking out about not being able to resell for 100x what the place is worth.

Comment: The most disturbing idea circulating here is "regulations to reduce the addictiveness of tobacco products". In plain language, this means reducing the nicotine content of cigarettes. The catch is, some theories of smoker behaviour posit that smokers inhale until they reach a desired dosage of nicotine, then taper off.

If that's true, then limiting nicotine would cause smokers to inhale MORE toxic products of combustion to reach their desired nicotine level. This policy could INCREASE harm by causing smokers to inhale more smoke in order to get the nicotine they want. It is basically a crank idea with no real-world backing, being promoted by ostensible experts who ought to know better. Very worrying.

As for Mr. Cunningham's (of the Canadian Cancer Society) comments — what's the point in being a "world leader" in deploying risky, unproven health policy with the potential to create vast, negative unintended consequences? Innovation in bad ideas is not a virtue!!

Comment: The labour force movements are a lagging rather than a leading indicator of output and the strong January numbers are a reflection of the strong December growth that finally took the economy to a real GDP per member of the active population level that exceeded its December 2014 peak. They don’t necessarily portend strong growth for the first quarter. The unemployment rate can be a volatile indicator; if one takes a centred three-month moving average of the unemployment rate there is still a drop in the unemployment rate to 6.8%, in December rather than January. We will have to wait for February to know what the smoothed unemployment rate for that month is.

Comment: Beautiful story. I hope they both continue to beat the odds and share many more happy years.

On the other end of the age spectrum, a child in my neighborhood has needed a new heart literally since birth. He wasn't expected to see any of his last five birthdays, but the courageous little warrior battles on. Unfortunately, Eugene is too far from a heart transplant center for him to even be on the list, and at his age there are so few suitable donors it doesn't make sense to uproot everyone just yet. Someday, that will happen, and hopefully it goes as well for him as it has for Mr. Hickey.

Comment: Bishop Tom,
The vision of:  mission->vocation->witness as found in the Gospels perfectly sums up the earthy-human life of Jesus of Nazareth as was evident from Bethlehem to Golgotha.
